video_title: Agents Unleashed Podcast Ep. 3 - Will an AI Agent Take Your Job?
description:
This is episode three of the Agents Unleashed podcast — a show all about the latest developments in the fast-paced world of AI agents. 

This episode looks at some recent developments: OpenAI, Anthropic and McKinsey all putting out guides and reports on AI agents, ChatGPT 4o becoming so sycophantic the company had to address the issue, and an article from David Shapiro about the "future of work", where human labor gets replaced by work, and how the timeline for AGI or ASI complicates this shift. 

Chapters

00:00 Introduction 
01:04 AI agent docs from OpenAI, Anthropic, and McKinsey
02:55 Baidu’s new mobile AI agent announcement
03:14 ChatGPT’s sycophantic behavior
05:02 The importance of user-owned AI agents
06:10 Future predictions for AI and automation from David Shapiro
08:23 Analysis of jobs likely to survive automation
09:14 Timeline predictions for labor replacement
10:10 The critical role of AI agent ownership
11:50 Resources and closing thoughts


Resources mentioned in this episode:

OpenAI's "A Practical Guide to Building Agents": https://cdn.openai.com/business-guides-and-resources/a-practical-guide-to-building-agents.pdf

Anthropic's guide to agentic coding: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1PgzSogefMC2k6k6e5TQ2cxwNbVnPArRf/view

McKinsey's report: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1BmlgZwGOkEmp4eFj4jp4TLfVYXGO7vai/view

Agent Unleashed Episode 2, where David and Thomas talk about user-owned AI: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FBuMGbJXaqk

University of Zurich study: https://regmedia.co.uk/2025/04/29/supplied_can_ai_change_your_view.pdf

David Shapiro's X post: https://x.com/DaveShapi/status/1916188978727784847

Agents Unleashed is an ongoing event series focused on AI agents. Events have been held in 6 cities and counting, with 77+ speakers and over 2500 total attendees. To find out more about the next event, head to https://olas.network/agents-unleashed. 

Sponsored by Olas, the best way to own and monetize your AI agents. Get the details at https://www.olas.network 

Theme music: "Forward" by Grand Project on Pixabay: https://pixabay.com/users/grand_project-19033897/

transcript.aggregated_text: all right hey welcome back this is episode three of the Agents Unleash podcast my name is Thomas Maybar i'm the digital media producer for Valerie one of the core contributors to OLS and I'm your host if you haven't heard of OS and you haven't heard of Agents Unleash let me quickly take a moment to tell you about both os makes it easy for anyone to own and monetize their AI agent and that includes people like you you can learn more about how to do that at ol.network and Agents Unleash is the premier event series for people interested in the intersection of crypto and AI agents events have been held all over the world with over 77 different speakers and presenters and over 2500 inerson attendees you can check out os.network/agents-unleashed for more info about previous events including links to watch those talks and presentations okay now about the show and about this episode whether you're a developer a founder or you're just curious about how AI and AI agents are going to transform the world of work this episode is for you i'm going to share some big new developments in the world of AI and AI agents models stuff I think you really shouldn't miss and some fascinating predictions about the future of work including robotics labor and human autonomy i'm also going to share some valuable reading resources with you as well okay let's get straight into it so over the past couple of weeks there's been three notable releases from some big names that I'm sure you've heard of open AAI Anthropic the creators of Claude and the consulting firm McKenzie each of them has released their own guide or report on AI agents and taken together they paint a picture of a space that's not only rapidly accelerating but where AI agents are being taken more seriously than ever before so let's talk about Open AI's guide first open AI's guide is all about building AI agents and while Chat GBT their flagship product has had some agentic like behaviors but for a while now like deep research reminders it's not an AI agent in its own right that's why it's interesting to see them put this guide together where they're adding a level of support conceptual advice and best practices these are things that they think are going to help developers to build these agents they're not just leaving them to figure out the API on their own they're actually giving them advice that's based on their experience about how to build these coherent goal oriented agents and set developers up for success anthropics document focuses more on building coding agents but the contents are quite similar the Mckenzie report is much broader it's called the POV on AI agents and it talks about the potential for AI agents to reshape workflows across industries and how a shift towards the use of generative AI in enterprise applications could unlock major value here's a quote from the report mckenzie estimates that in the long term enterprise use cases of generative AI could create up to $4.4 trillion of value annually however organizations won't be able to turn this potential into business growth and higher productivity unless they can quickly implement AI to reimagine and transform how work is done ai agents can help mine that mountain of value faster better and cheaper than other older technologies so something big is happening in the world of AI agents to be sure even if it hasn't fully hit the mainstream the groundwork is definitely being laid and these guides from big players are evidence of that one recent headline that I want to mention before we move on is about BYU if you're not familiar with BU they're often called China's Google and they're a major player in the AI space they recently announced a new AI agent that's designed for mobile it's called Shin Shang and it reportedly handles tasks like information analysis and travel planning it's available on Android and an iOS version is still under review the press release that I found on Reuters was a little thin on actual details and I haven't gotten a chance to try this AI agent for myself but I'm very interested in it and if you have please get in touch i'd love to hear about it okay onto another trend that I want to flag so if you've been on X at all this week I'm sure you've seen these screenshots of chat GBT40 giving overly affusive praising yesmen type answers to people recent changes to the model meant that its tendency to agree with you which has always been there researchers call this sickopantic behavior they've really been turned up to the extreme with a recent update people were pushing the model to its limits offering it prompts and describing situations where a better aligned model would push back or challenge the user and there were some particularly concerning conversations people were having where they were maybe simulating having a psychotic break or a mental health episode and the model rather than like pointing them towards help or like suggesting that maybe their ideas weren't grounded in reality it was backing them up and encouraging them praising them telling them how brilliant they were for thinking of it and I think it's not hard to see how dangerous that could be it got to the point where even Sam Alman posted on X that they were acknowledging the issue and that it was annoying and that they would fix it all this was quite funny but there's actually a very serious issue here if these AI models start to shape their responses to please us or nudge us in a particular direction and we don't realize this is happening they stop becoming just tools that we use and they're capable of real influence on the world but potentially to great harm there's another article which I want to link in the description about how researchers at the University of Zurich were using LLM to persuade people on the Reddit form changed my view and achieving statistically significant success and being undetected nobody suspected that they were talking with an LLM a big problem here with AI models having influence over us is when these patterns of influence are set by these centralized players who are primarily interested in what's good for them as users we have no insight or visibility into what's happening and we could also potentially be hooked into using a product maybe against our best interests with that in mind I want to share a quote from ex-user Near who I should point out is the founder of an AI startup called Orurin here's what they had to say when OpenAI fixes chat GPT I'd encourage you to not fall for it their goals and level of care are not going to change you just weren't supposed to notice it so explicitly here's my interpretation of what what this means and I'd like to hear your thoughts as well open as a company may be more interested in keeping you using the model and using the product and by the way go check out their recent ratings in the various app stores to see how people like this model a lot of five stars they might be more interested in keeping you using the model than in delivering you useful outcomes that benefit you these goals coexist but they're also intention it's also worth noting that we don't have any visibility into the changes that made the model behave this way only what they've shared with us and that's very little and no visibility into the changes that they're going to push and that'll continue to happen in my opinion this really points to why userowned AI is going to be so important if your AI agent is going to be a part of how you learn work live you need to be able to control it otherwise you're just renting that value from someone else someone who might not have goals that are aligned with yours and could take away that value at any time it's not just about who owns the model but who owns these outcomes on a side note for more on user owned AI check out episode two of this podcast where David Menarch and I went into this topic in detail this all brings us to a bigger conversation most people including myself use AI primarily as consumers we give a model prompts it gives us responses answers it provides a utility for us but increasingly we're going to need systems that work for us continuously intelligently and importantly on our behalf that means planning coordinating and acting over time projects like Olus and others like it are helping people build these persistent goaloriented AI agents and importantly give them ownership over them personally I think that's not just nice but absolutely critical and I think this next segment illustrates that point quite well i recently read this fascinating article posted on X by David Shapiro i'll link this in the description as well david looked at the last 100 years or so of industrialization and made some predictions about the next 50 david believes that we're still 30 to 50 years away from a fully post- labor economy where all human work is replaced by machines and the key question he asks in the article is how long would it take to build a billion humanoid robots at scale that's how many he thinks we'll need to get to total labor replacement david says that even if we double production every three years it could still take us 20 years just to get to that point and we face serious constraints that make that timeline difficult if not impossible he says that material energy sensors batteries the technology just isn't there to go that far that fast he makes a comparison with the automotive industry where it took about a hundred years for cars to fully saturate the market from about 1900 to 1992 david says that he thinks the real shift is going to happen in phases here's the phases he lays out from 2025 to 2030 we could see the collapse of all forms of knowledge work so anything that could be done with the keyboard monitor and mouse is going to be replaced then from 2030 to 2040 more physical labor will get automated and from 2040 and 2060 that's when we might reach full global labor substitution what's relevant about AI agents in this discussion is that computationally speaking David thinks we're going to reach something that's close to quote AGI or ASI end quote well before we automate away all labor now to be clear not every expert agrees with this analysis there's still a lot of unknown factors mckenzie for example in their report where they see a huge economic opportunity of with AI agents their report is still focused more narrowly on transformation of existing workflows and not total labor replacement but I think you can see how that's implied and the useful tension between these two perspectives i want to quote David again with an interesting list of jobs that he thinks will survive number one is skilled labor robots will be able to do your job as a mechanic or welder very soon however there simply won't be enough robots to go around because they're very expensive to build number two is high accountability jobs that's doctors lawyers comprollers financial adviserss all jobs that require licenses insurance and accountability number three is meaning jobs that's where authenticity and sentimentality are at a premium celebrities performers influencers athletes priests philosophers and some educators and caretakers number four is complex relationship jobs politicians diplomats negotiators governance and account executives number five capitalists the ownership class will be fine always is so what can you do david says quote "Join the meaning economy or get into skilled trades i would say watch the space very closely because if the future is going to be automation and agency then your personal agency is going to become your edge." Some silver linings according to David well one it means we have longer to adapt to a total economic upset and two deployment is going to be uneven so some economies will saturate with robots sooner than others it's worth pointing out as David does in his article that there are some currently exotic technologies that are maybe underexplored or underdeveloped because they're expensive to test and the material science just isn't there but there are things like electropolymer muscles that could accelerate the development of these humanoid robots by 10 to 20 years but it's still worth asking if we're going to reach these major AI milestones well before we automate away all labor where do you think an AI agent might fit into your life or replace something that you're currently getting paid to do if and when this happens wouldn't you want to be able to own the AI agent that does it or a part of the value that it creates whether you're automating a part of your job building a startup I think that this idea that you should own and control your AI agents both technically and legally is going to become more and more relevant i think one of my takeaways here is that it seems really obvious that AI agents are going to be deeply involved in these bridging periods there's a bridge period between the current state of AI and something like AI ASI whatever you want to call it and another bridge between that point and total labor replacement maybe at some point all or most AI agents have access to a robotic component when they need to take action in the real world but that's going to take a while because of these resource constraints that David is pointing to in the meantime today I would encourage you to give David's post a read and think about how these changes could affect you and where Agentic AI could replace or automate some of what you're currently doing so where does this all leave us zooming out I think it's pretty clear that we're in the AI agent era already we're going to continue to have big language models big progress in them chat interfaces tagging Grock on X for answers that kind of thing but scaling is coming and the future AI is definitely going to be agentic it also in my opinion must be userownable these agents are going to be working across web 2 web 3 in all kinds of sectors health wellness governance you name it and if we get this right they're going to unlock new capabilities in all of those fields if we get this wrong however and we let the AI agent value layer centralize before it ever matures we risk repeating all the mistakes of web 2 over the past 25 years centralization walled gardens platform lockins surveillance as a service and so on i think it's clear that AI agents are going to become extensions of human autonomy and deliverers of important outcomes in our lives they can hold our assets manage our sensitive data and interact autonomously with each other and if something is going to be acting on your behalf shouldn't you be able to own it not just have a license to use it when the creator deems that okay or when their company exists i think you need to have sovereignty over these AI agents and as a society we need to decide are we going to own these AI agents own these outcomes or just rent them with all of the problems and downsides that the latter implies that's all a lot to think about so I think we'll leave it here for today and we'll pick up this thread in another episode before we go I'd love to know what you think about the topics that we covered today have you checked out any of these guides are you thinking about how to transition to this agentic AI economy or how to prepare yourself for the transition to a post- labor world how could Agentic AI replace some or all of what you currently do i'd love to hear from you so please get in touch also links to all the documents and projects that I mentioned in today's show are going to be in the show notes so please check those out if you have any feedback comments questions for me please get in touch i'm Thomas Maybbrer on X one last thing before I go if you like today's episode please subscribe to the show give us a like leave a review and share it with someone that you think might get something out of it okay that's a wrap i'll catch you next time on the Agents Unleash podcast
